items.title: Startups Weekly: Startups raised funding to help others navigate challenges
items.author: Anna Heim
items.summary:
- Fintech startup Ramp more than doubled its annualized revenue to $700 million and nearly doubled its valuation to $13 billion.
- Revenue prediction startup Gong surpassed $300 million in annualized revenue, indicating a potential IPO path.
- Mach Industries landed a contract with the U.S. Army and plans to build its first factory.
- Ryan Breslow returns as CEO of Bolt after a settled legal controversy.
- Passes has been sued for allegedly distributing child sexual abuse material.
- Aspiration faced legal issues with one board member pleading guilty to wire fraud.
- Anthropic raised $3.5 billion at a $61.5 billion valuation to fuel its AI ambitions.
- Turing raised $111 million to assist in building large language models.
- Indian HR unicorn Darwinbox raised $140 million for international expansion.
- Defense tech startup Epirus raised $250 million to counter drone swarms.
- New York-based Ataraxis AI raised $20.4 million to personalize cancer treatment.
- Foundation Capital raised a $600 million fund, 20% more than its previous fund.

items.title: Health Expert Warns of Leaning Too Heavily on AI for Social Connections
items.author: Kasley Killam, Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Experts caution against relying too much on AI companions for social interactions.
- Kasley Killam emphasizes that AI should augment, not replace, real-world relationships.
- Research shows a significant rise in AI companion app revenue, indicating a growing dependence on technology for companionship.

items.title: DeepSeek: Everything you need to know about the AI chatbot app
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- DeepSeek has become popular after topping the Apple App Store and Google Play charts.
- The company is backed by High-Flyer Capital Management, a Chinese hedge fund co-founded by Liang Wenfeng.
- DeepSeek's AI models have led to significant scrutiny over the U.S. maintaining its AI leadership.
- The company launched its first models in November 2023, with notable performance improvements in the subsequent DeepSeek-V2 and V3. 
- DeepSeek's R1 model reportedly performs well on reasoning tasks but avoids sensitive topics due to regulations.
- Its pricing strategy disrupts the market, but some experts question its cost figures.
- DeepSeek has faced bans from various companies and countries due to data security concerns, including New York State and South Korea.
- The U.S. government is considering a ban on DeepSeek for government devices amid national security concerns.

items.title: US charges admins of Garantex for allegedly facilitating crypto money laundering for terrorists and hackers
items.summary:
- The U.S. Department of Justice charged Garantex administrators for facilitating money laundering by criminal organizations and violating U.S. sanctions.
- Administrators Aleksej Besciokov and Aleksandr Mira Serda face up to 20 years in prison for money laundering, with additional charges for Besciokov.
- Garantex allegedly processed at least $96 billion in cryptocurrency transactions since 2019 and received hundreds of millions in criminal proceeds.
- Law enforcement seized $26 million and took down Garantex’s official websites just a day prior to the indictment.

items.title: Google adds a Gemini panel to Calendar to help you manage your schedule
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Google is testing a new AI-powered Gemini side panel in Google Calendar for scheduling tasks.
- Users can check their schedule, create events, and retrieve event details conversationally.
- The feature is part of Google Workspace Labs’ early access testing program.
- Gemini can be accessed via the “Ask Gemini” icon and offers suggested prompts or allows custom queries.
- This feature aims to streamline calendar management and reduce manual searching for events.
- Gemini panels are already available in other Google apps such as Gmail and Google Drive. Rollout details for other users are unspecified.

items.title: NTT Com Confirms Data Breach Affected Nearly 18,000 Organizations
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- NTT Communications confirmed hackers accessed the data of almost 18,000 corporate customers in a cyberattack detected on February 5.
- Stolen data includes names, contract numbers, and contact information for 17,891 organizations.
- NTT Com has over 100,000 corporate customers in 70 countries.
- The company restricted access to compromised devices after discovering the breach and found a second compromised device on February 15.
- The attackers and specific nature of the cyberattack remain unknown.

items.title: Russian propaganda reportedly influencing AI chatbot results
items.summary:
- Russian propaganda may be influencing AI chatbot responses, particularly OpenAI’s ChatGPT and Meta’s Meta AI.
- A report from NewsGuard reveals a Moscow-based network named “Pravda” is publishing false claims to skew AI models' outputs.
- Pravda published 3.6 million misleading articles in 2024, utilizing search engine optimization to increase the visibility of pro-Russian narratives.
- AI chatbots repeated false Russian disinformation narratives 33% of the time based on NewsGuard's analysis.

items.title: CollX raises $10M to grow its card collection marketplace
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- CollX has raised $10 million in Series A funding.
- The funding round was co-led by Brand Foundry Ventures and 114 Ventures, with participation from Next Coast Ventures, FJ Labs, and Ben Franklin Technology Partners.
- Kansas City Royals player Bobby Witt Jr. joins as an investor and brand ambassador.
- CollX has raised over $15 million in total and has grown its user base to over 3 million.
- The marketplace hosts 30,000 buyers and 20,000 sellers, with 400,000 monthly active users.
- CollX offers features like card scanning, trading, and new revenue streams including card grading referrals and partnerships for live shopping.
- The company has launched a pro subscription service and an AI feature to assist users with their collections.

items.title: Last day to apply to be a TechCrunch Sessions: AI speaker
items.summary:
- TechCrunch Sessions: AI takes place on June 5 at Zellerbach Hall, UC Berkeley.
- Apply to be a speaker by 11:59 p.m. PT tonight to lead breakout sessions and discussions.
- Applicants can submit a topic via the TC Sessions: AI event page for audience voting on sessions.

items.title: Meta’s next Llama models may have upgraded voice features
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Meta's upcoming Llama 4 model is expected to focus on enhanced voice features.
- The model will allow users to interrupt mid-speech, similar to features in OpenAI's Voice Mode and Google's Gemini Live.
- Meta's chief product officer, Chris Cox, described Llama 4 as an “omni” model for interpreting and producing speech and text.
- Competition from DeepSeek's open models has accelerated Llama's development process.

items.title: X now lets you query Grok by mentioning it in replies
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- X expands accessibility of xAI’s Grok model by allowing users to mention Grok in replies for explanations.
- Users can previously access Grok via a sidebar button and get explanations for posts.
- The Grok chatbot now has a standalone app for iOS and Android, as well as a dedicated site and a new SuperGrok plan offering extra features.

items.title: FBI says scammers are targeting US executives with fake BianLian ransom notes
items.summary:
- The FBI warns of scammers impersonating the BianLian ransomware gang with fake ransom notes targeting U.S. executives.
- Scammers demand between $250,000 and $500,000, threatening to publish stolen data unless a ransom is paid.
- The notes include a QR code linked to a Bitcoin wallet and a return address in Boston, Massachusetts.
- The BianLian gang has targeted U.S. critical infrastructure since June 2022; however, no known victims have been disclosed by the FBI.

items.title: SpaceX Starship spirals out of control in second straight test flight failure
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- SpaceX's Starship experienced a out-of-control flight during a test on Thursday, marking a second consecutive failure.
- The FAA briefly halted flights into major Florida airports due to concerns over space launch debris.
- The vehicle lost multiple Raptor engines approximately eight minutes into the flight and began to spiral, leading to a loss of contact with it shortly thereafter.
- Footage showed the Starship breaking up over the Bahamas and Dominican Republic shortly after the failure.
- SpaceX was attempting to deploy four dummy Starlink satellites during this test flight.
- This test followed a previous failure that prompted an FAA investigation into propellant leaks causing a communications blackout.

items.title: Google co-founder Larry Page reportedly has a new AI startup
items.summary:
- Larry Page is launching a new AI startup called Dynatomics focused on product manufacturing.
- The startup aims to use AI for creating "highly optimized" designs for objects, and then automate their production.
- Chris Anderson, former CTO of Kittyhawk, is leading this stealth project.
- Other companies, such as Orbital Materials and PhysicsX, are also exploring AI applications in manufacturing and engineering.

items.title: A second Intuitive Machines spacecraft just landed on the moon — and probably tipped over
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- Intuitive Machines' spacecraft Athena landed on the moon on March 6, 2025, at around 12:30 p.m. ET.
- The lander appears to have tipped over after touchdown, as per the CEO's statements during the post-landing press conference.
- This marks the second private lunar landing this week, following Firefly Aerospace’s Blue Ghost on March 2.
- Athena launched aboard a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket on February 26, 2025.
- The mission carries critical technologies, including a laser retroreflector and an ice mining experiment for NASA, as well as a rover named MAPP for testing cellular equipment.

items.title: Anthropic’s Claude Code tool had a bug that ‘bricked’ some systems
items.summary:
- Anthropic’s coding tool, Claude Code, experienced issues after launch due to buggy auto-update commands.
- Reports indicated that these commands rendered some workstations unstable and broken, particularly when installed with superuser permissions.
- The commands altered access permissions of critical system files, leading to significant issues for users, prompting fixes through a rescue instance.
- Anthropic has since removed the problematic commands and provided a troubleshooting guide for affected users, correcting an initial typo in the link.

items.title: Scale AI is being investigated by the US Department of Labor
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- The U.S. Department of Labor is investigating Scale AI for compliance with the Fair Labor Standards Act.
- The investigation began in August 2024 and concerns unpaid wages and misclassification of employees.
- Scale AI claims to have worked with the DOL to clarify its business practices and insists it provides flexible job opportunities.

items.title: ChatGPT doubled its weekly active users in under 6 months, thanks to new releases
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- ChatGPT's weekly active users increased from 200 million to 400 million in less than six months.
- Growth followed new releases including the GPT-4o model and Advanced Voice Mode.
- Significant user engagement continues on mobile, with 175 million out of 400 million weekly users on the app.
- Competitor app DeepSeek reached No. 2 globally in 10 days, capturing 15% of ChatGPT’s mobile user base.

items.title: Hacked health firm HCRG demanded journalist ‘take down’ data breach reporting, citing UK court order
items.author: Zack Whittaker
items.summary:
- A U.S.-based cybersecurity journalist refused to comply with a U.K. court injunction regarding articles on HCRG's ransomware attack.
- HCRG's law firm, Pinsent Masons, demanded the removal of articles referencing the breach, claiming the injunction was to protect confidential data.
- The journalist argued that DataBreaches.net is not subject to U.K. jurisdiction and that the reporting is protected under the First Amendment in the U.S.
- HCRG was confirmed to have been attacked on February 20, losing two terabytes of data, with over 5,000 employees impacted.
- The injunction could potentially limit journalistic reporting on cybersecurity breaches involving U.K. entities.

items.title: Hugging Face’s chief science officer worries AI is becoming ‘yes-men on servers’
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Thomas Wolf from Hugging Face warns AI is at risk of being merely obedient and lacking creativity.
- He stresses that current AI lacks the ability to generate new knowledge or ask unique questions.
- Wolf contrasts his views with other AI leaders like Sam Altman and Dario Amodei, who have optimistic predictions for AI’s potential.
- He calls for a shift in how AI evaluation benchmarks are set to promote more innovative thinking.

items.title: Shield AI raises $240M at a $5.3B valuation to commercialize its AI drone tech
items.summary:
- Shield AI raised $240 million at a $5.3 billion valuation as announced on March 6, 2025.
- The company specializes in AI-powered military systems and wants to expand its Hivemind software to a wider range of customers, including robotics firms.
- Investors include defense contractor L3Harris and Hanwha Aerospace, as well as Andreessen Horowitz.
- This funding round makes Shield AI the second-largest defense tech startup in the U.S. by valuation, following Anduril.

items.title: Russian crypto exchange Garantex seized by law enforcement operation
Christie’s AI art auction reportedly exceeds expectations
items.summary:
- Nearly 6,500 artists petitioned Christie’s to cancel its AI art auction, Augmented Intelligence.
- The auction generated over $700,000, surpassing expectations.
- Top sale was Anadol’s “Machine Hallucinations — ISS Dreams — A” which sold for $277,200.
- Nicole Sales Giles, Christie’s VP, states the auction success indicates recognition for innovative artists.
- Concerns remain over the use of copyrighted material in AI-generated art, according to artists' open letter.

items.title: ChatGPT on macOS can now directly edit code
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- ChatGPT can now directly edit code on macOS in tools like Xcode, VS Code, and JetBrains.
- An “auto-apply” mode allows for edits without additional clicks.
- Available for ChatGPT Plus, Pro, and Team subscribers as of March 6, 2025; Enterprise, Edu, and free users will receive it next week.
- The feature builds on the “work with apps” capability launched in November 2024.
- The move positions ChatGPT against AI coding tools like Cursor and GitHub Copilot.
- AI coding assistants are gaining popularity, with many developers using AI-generated code; however, there are associated risks.

items.title: Spotify says it’s fixing the bug that caused Premium users to hear ads
What is Mistral AI? Everything to know about the OpenAI competitor
items.summary:
- Mistral AI, based in France, is recognized as a leading tech startup and potential competitor to OpenAI, with a valuation of $6 billion.
- The company launched its AI assistant, Le Chat, which reached 1 million downloads in 14 days after its mobile release, supported by endorsements from French President Emmanuel Macron.
- Founded in 2023, Mistral AI focuses on openness in AI with several models, including Mistral Large 2, Pixtral Large, and Codestral. It raised approximately €1 billion in funding and has strategic partnerships with major companies including Microsoft and IBM.

items.title: VW’s cheapest EV will have Rivian DNA and who is bidding for Canoo’s assets
items.summary:
- Volkswagen unveils the ID EVERY1, its cheapest EV, set to launch in 2027 with a starting price of €20,000 ($21,500).
- The vehicle will be the first to feature software and architecture from Rivian, part of a $5.8 billion joint venture.
- The ID.2all, another affordable EV, is expected to be released in 2026, utilizing software developed by VW's Cariad unit.
- Canoo's CEO Anthony Aquila is buying nearly all assets of the bankrupt EV startup for $4 million.

items.title: Founder of battery startup Our Next Energy returns as CEO following new funding
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Mujeeb Ijaz returns as CEO of Our Next Energy (ONE) after being replaced in December 2023.
- The company closed a new funding round led by Crescent Ventures and Trousdale Ventures, but details about the size were not disclosed.
- ONE faced financial difficulties, laying off 128 employees and experiencing a stalled Series C funding effort after Just Climate withdrew.
- The startup is building a $1.6 billion LFP battery factory in Michigan and previously raised $300 million in Series B funding.
- Ijaz's brother, Mansoor, has joined the board as part of the leadership transition.

items.title: TechCrunch Sessions: AI speaker applications close tomorrow, submit yours today
OpenAI’s ex-policy lead criticizes the company for ‘rewriting’ its AI safety history
items.author: Miles Brundage
items.summary:
- Miles Brundage, ex-OpenAI policy researcher, criticized OpenAI for altering its AI safety history.
- OpenAI recently released a document outlining its philosophy on AI safety, emphasizing iterative deployment.
- Brundage argued that the release of GPT-2 was consistent with cautious deployment, contrary to OpenAI's claims.
- He expressed concern that the new document demonstrates a dangerous mentality towards safety in AI systems.
- Competitive pressures and financial losses could lead OpenAI to prioritize speed over safety in its product releases.

items.title: Mistral’s new OCR API turns any PDF document into an AI-ready Markdown file
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Mistral launched a new optical character recognition API called [Mistral OCR](https://mistral.ai/news/mistral-ocr) for developers handling complex PDF documents.
- The API converts PDFs into formatted Markdown text including bounding boxes for illustrations and photos.
- Mistral OCR claims superior performance compared to Google, Microsoft, and OpenAI APIs, especially with complex documents and non-English text.
- It is designed for organizations to streamline access to large amounts of internal documentation, enhancing capabilities for AI assistants.

items.title: Intangible AI, a no-code 3D creation tool for filmmakers and game designers, raises $4M
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Intangible AI has raised $4 million in seed funding for its AI-powered 3D creation tool, targeting filmmakers, game designers, and everyday users.
- The tool allows users to create 3D concepts with text prompts, without the need for coding.
- It is set to officially launch in June, offering both free and paid subscription tiers ranging from $15 to $50 per month.
- The company is co-founded by Charles Migos, a former Apple designer, and Bharat Vasan, an entrepreneur previously with Basis.
- Their product currently in closed beta has attracted interest from numerous creatives, including major film and gaming studios.
- Funding will support product development and hiring, aiming to double the team size this year.

items.title: Why VCs ghost founders, or reject deals and never speak to the founder again
items.summary:
- Ghosting by VCs signifies a lack of interest in a founder's pitch.
- Time constraints and increased volume of pitches lead to less communication from VCs.
- Red flags that may lead to rejection include unrealistic expectations, visible team issues, and dishonesty.

items.title: DuckDuckGo leans further into GenAI as its AI chat interface exits beta
items.summary:
- DuckDuckGo is expanding its generative AI capabilities with the launch of Duck.ai, now out of beta.
- Users can access AI models from Anthropic, OpenAI, and Meta through a chatbot interface.
- The service features daily query limits, with plans for a paid option for more extensive AI chat capabilities.
- DuckDuckGo's search engine now includes AI-assisted answers, appearing over 20% of the time if opted for frequently.
- Users can control the level of AI responses, with options like 'sometimes,' 'often,' 'on-demand,' and 'never.'
- Notably, DuckDuckGo promises privacy, allowing use of AI models without tracking or account creation.
- The service allows seamless switching between chat and traditional search results with an easy-to-use chat button.

items.title: Armis buys Otorio for $120M to beef up cybersecurity in physical spaces
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Armis acquires Otorio for $120 million in cash and shares, enhancing cybersecurity in industrial and physical environments.
- Otorio’s flagship product, Titan, will integrate into Armis’ Centrix platform.
- This acquisition marks Armis’ third purchase in a year, following Silk Security and CTCI acquisitions.
- The move is part of a trend where early-stage cyber startups opt for acquisitions as funding becomes concentrated in late-stage companies.

items.title: How Uber’s new product chief is gearing up for robotaxis
Faireez raises $7.5M for AI-powered hotel-style housekeeping for condo residents
Reddit adds new tools to help users contribute and connect across its platform
Google DeepMind, Cohere, and Twelve Labs explain how founders can build with their AI models at TechCrunch Sessions: AI
Anthropic submits AI policy recommendations to the White House
Turing, a key coding provider for OpenAI and other LLM producers, raises $111M at a $2.2B valuation
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Turing raises $111 million in Series E funding, doubling its valuation to $2.2 billion.
- The company reports an annualized revenue run rate of $167 million and is profitable.
- Khazanah Nasional Berhad leads the funding round, joined by several other investors.
- Turing originally started as an HR tech startup but shifted focus to developing AI coding solutions after working with OpenAI.

items.title: A year later, OpenAI still hasn’t released its voice cloning tool
items.summary:
- OpenAI announced a preview of its voice cloning tool, Voice Engine, in March 2024, but it remains in preview a year later without a public launch date.
- The company remains cautious about the tool's release, citing concerns over potential misuse and regulatory scrutiny.
- Voice Engine has been in development since 2022 and aims to generate realistic speech while ensuring user safety through features like watermarking and consent requirements.

items.title: Crogl, armed with $30M, takes the wraps off a new AI ‘Iron Man suit’ for security analysts
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Crogl debuts an autonomous assistant for cybersecurity researchers, dubbed an 'Iron Man suit' for analysts.
- The startup has raised $30 million, including a $25 million Series A led by Menlo Ventures.
- The tool helps analysts manage a large volume of security alerts, aiming to enhance their decision-making capabilities.
- Crogl's CEO Monzy Merza brings extensive security industry experience from roles at Sandia, Splunk, and HSBC.

items.title: UK quietly scrubs encryption advice from government websites
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- The U.K. government has removed encryption advice from its websites following a demand for backdoor access to encrypted data on iCloud.
- The change was noticed by security expert Alec Muffet, indicating that the National Cyber Security Centre no longer recommends encryption for high-risk individuals.
- Previously recommended tools like Apple's Advanced Data Protection (ADP) have been replaced with a suggestion to use Lockdown Mode, which limits access to functions.
- The original guidance document has been deleted, while Apple has confirmed it will no longer offer end-to-end encryption for new U.K. users.

items.title: A quarter of startups in YC’s current cohort have codebases that are almost entirely AI-generated
Renaissance Fusion raises €32M to radically simplify complex fusion reactors
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Renaissance Fusion secured €32 million in Series A1 funding led by Crédit Mutuel Impact’s Révolution Environnementale et Solidaire fund and Lowercarbon Capital.
- The funds will be used to build a demonstrator for a simplified stellarator fusion reactor design, aiming for completion by the end of 2026.
- The innovative design incorporates segmented tubes and high-temperature superconducting magnets, with a focus on reducing manufacturing complexity and costs for fusion technology.

items.title: Alpine Eagle secures funding from European backers for counter-drone tech amid rising threats
items.author: Anna Heim
items.summary:
- The war in Ukraine has increased demand for counter-drone systems.  
- German startup Alpine Eagle develops Sentinel, an airborne counter-drone system designed for cost efficiency.  
- The startup secured €10.25 million in Series A funding, with the German army as its launch customer and plans to expand into the U.K. market.

items.title: Infineon teams up with India’s CDIL to explore business in light EVs, energy storage solutions
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- Infineon Technologies partners with India’s CDIL to explore electric mobility and renewable energy solutions.
- India aims to increase EV penetration from 7-8% to 30% and raise non-fossil energy generation from 100GW to 500GW by 2030.
- Collaboration involves supplying wafers for packaging at CDIL's facility in Mohali for products targeting light EVs and energy storage.

items.title: Tapbots teases a new Bluesky app, Phoenix, saying it can’t ‘survive on Mastodon alone’
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Tapbots is developing a new app called Phoenix for Bluesky, set to launch in summer 2025.
- The company acknowledges the need to support both Bluesky and Mastodon, stating it can’t thrive on Mastodon alone.
- Development on Ivory, the Mastodon client, will temporarily slow down during Phoenix’s creation, though both apps will receive future improvements.
- Phoenix will likely follow a subscription model similar to Ivory, which costs $1.99 per month or $14.99 per year.
- A limited public alpha phase for Phoenix will occur before its official launch.

items.title: Canoo’s CEO is buying the bankrupt EV startup’s assets
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- Canoo's CEO, Anthony Aquila, is purchasing nearly all assets of the bankrupt EV startup for $4 million.
- The sale will eliminate over $11 million in debt owed by Canoo to Aquila's financial firm.
- Canoo filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy just six weeks prior, citing $145 million in assets against $175 million in liabilities.
- Other offers for Canoo's assets can be submitted before March 28.
- The bankruptcy trustee supports the sale due to a lack of financing options for EV manufacturing and the high number of available assets from failed startups.
